posts.name: L
posts.cooked:
Hello Chief Delphi,

During my team’s week five competition, a new problem appeared out of nowhere: The battery voltage would get down to less than 7 volts during normal operation in matches. We have not made any significant changes since our last competition, code and mechanical.

I do not have logs with me right now, but I can tell you what I saw. The battery voltage in the drivertstation’s log oscillated very rapidly (about every second, sometimes less) between 12 volts and about 8. For two matches, the battery voltage would dip so low that the radio would lose power and have to restart. The batteries are the same that we use for practice sessions, which are equally as intense as they are during a match.

Looking at Phoenix SignalLogger files, no other motors have current spikes nearly as frequent or high as our MK4i drive motors (L2). The slip current is set at the default 300 Amps (using the PhoenixTuner Swerve Generated Project code), and we completely forgot to adjust it until our first competition. However, we did not notice any of these problems in our first competition, so we did not prioritize tuning this current limit. Every other motor on our robot is current limited to something reasonable, like 40A or 60A, expect for the swerve motors (this includes drive and steer).

We did a lot of electrical repairs which did help (battery only dropped to about 8 volts), but the issue is still present and we are looking to software fixes. One thing we were wondering is if the PhoenixTuner swerve code has closed loop ramp rates, and if that may be necessary.

Any ideas or thoughts are appreciated. Thanks in advance!

Edit: I forgot to mention that we change the slip current (stator current) of the drive motors to 60A for our elimination matches, which did completely mitigate the problem.

posts.name: John
posts.cooked:
Hey - I’m John from 2415 electrical

Our electrical fixes:

replaced all battery wire after measuring resistance in negative section

redid all VRM and PDH connections and checked for shorts

replaced radio

switched from barrel connection on radio to POE injector

checked all connections for shorts

tightened breaker terminals

After these changes, the drips weren’t as severe, though we still regularly saw voltage drops below 9V.

edit: forgot about breaker

posts.name: Justin Montois
posts.cooked: Check the power  lugs on your main breaker.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: We just had this issue at regional, and it presented as a low battery (very early in a match). The breaker terminals may look fine, but if you can rotate them by hand easily they are too loose.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
default 300a

Your drive motors are dying. 80A is fine. I’m surprised you haven’t browned out before this weekend, but I’d definitely consider swapping all four drive motors.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
If you don’t find anything else, it’s possible your batteries have been beat up to the point they have higher internal resistance, or intermittent higher resistance.  I suspect this happens when a battery takes severe mechanical shocks and some of the internal electrical pathways become damaged/de-rated in some way.  After last year, we started trying to provide some cushioning for our batteries.

But also check the terminal connections on all of your batteries.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: This is the " slip " current.  The newest tuner swerve generator sets it to 150.  This is actually stator current.  We haven’t had a problem with it.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
… we didn’t have a problem with it for about 2 weeks or so of pretty serious practice. Then motors started dying one by one.

Check your motor temperatures with an IR gun, if you’re seeing north of 140 f on the drive after a match, you’re starting to see the same failure mode we did. 100 to 105 f is still pretty normal.

Edit: the talonfx on the dying motor will start reporting a suspiciously stable ~40, instead of a value that jumps around kind of erratically. Don’t trust the software, literally put a ir thermometer on it.

Edit2: we let our driver use the whole drivetrain, if you have other slew limits or input limits you might not need a sane stator limit.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Do you have more details on what failure you’re seeing and what the cause and fix was? Are you saying you had a Kraken motor fail and it caused you to brown out?

posts.name: L
Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
If you want to do some analysis, look at data from before/good matches and after/bad matches.  Specifically, start by focusing on total current draw and voltage.  I wish there was a graph that showed voltage / total current.  (If you happen to maintain a log viewer, this would be a nice addition, with no additional telemetry required.)

This would be some kind of equivalent resistance for the robot as a whole.  You are looking for two possible answers:

Voltage went down because total current went up, with the equivalent resistance remaining roughly constant (at least for the same battery);

Voltage went down because total current went up, with the equivalent resistance remaining roughly constant (at least for the same battery);

Voltage went down because the equivalent resistance went up, with the total current draw from match-to-match staying similar.

Voltage went down because the equivalent resistance went up, with the total current draw from match-to-match staying similar.

For 1), you are looking for the cause of the higher current draw, and you can look at per-circuit current draws to help narrow this down.  Are your drive motors fighting each other?  Is there some kind of mechanical issue?  Maybe you are seeing motors that have started to cook off the insulation on their windings?  Once you figure out what changed, it should lead you to a narrower range of theories.

For 2), you are looking for the cause of the higher resistance.  Battery issues?  Wiring issues?  Breaker issue of some kind?

Another helpful approach is to put a thermal imager on the robot right after a hard match.  Look for hot spots – motors, breakers, connections, etc.  You are spending power producing heat, and you should find a consistent picture that tells a story of some kind.  If you find a surprise, you might have at least a partial answer.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
We were browning out as early as the midpoint of matches when we had 300A stator limits, and currently still see brownouts in the last fifteen or so seconds running 80A limits. That’s separate from motor failures. We ran almost two weeks at 300A.

The motor failures are detectable when the motor shafts no longer spin freely. Because the shafts no longer spin freely, the brownouts become much more frequent and motors get much hotter and the drive misbehaves.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
JaBong:

After these changes, the drips weren’t as severe, though we still regularly saw voltage drops below 9V.

That’s not all that weird. How regularly? Were there still brownouts after this point?

posts.name: L
posts.cooked:
Sorry for the late reply, we haven’t gotten much practice time since I wrote the question. Our team is at our district competition right now and the problem is effectively gone. I only see about 5-6 dips to 8 volts during a match and there are significantly less spikes/dips then before. Solutions:

3 of our battery’s internal resistances were high and had noticeably worse. The resistances were around 0.031 Ohms (measured from CTR battery beak), and the good ones we have are closer to 0.015.

Stator (slip) current limited all drive motors to 60A

Each drive motor has a ramp rate of 0.2 seconds now, our driver doesn’t notice any sluggishness

Current limited our intake motor which spiked quite a bit when toggled on (to about 60A)

posts.name: John
posts.cooked:
These changes fixed our problems. We are now monitoring and cycling batteries carefully.

Under .02 ohms - match battery Between .02 and .03 - practice battery Over .03 - not in use
